Les créatures qui se trouvent sur la trajectoire de ce cône doivent effectuer un jet de sauvegarde de {@dc 18} de Dextérité, subissant 42 ({@damage 12d6}) dégâts d'acide en cas d'échec, ou la moitié en cas de réussite.

Une odeur de terre fraîchement retournée et de soufre bouillonnant accompagne ce terrible monstre, un amalgame de bois et de chair rappelant vaguement un centaure géant aux membres osseux en bois. De vastes ailes draconiques sortent du dos de la créature, et elle porte une queue serpentine qui se termine par un hochet conique.

entries.name: Born of Dragons
entries: Lorsqu'un {@creature child of Yggdrasil|ToB} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}) particulièrement robuste rencontre le cadavre encore frais d'un dragon adulte ou plus âgé, il tente de dévorer le cœur du dragon et se métamorphose en une aberration plus grande et plus vicieuse connue sous le nom d'empereur des forêts. Ce processus prend une semaine et, tout en se transformant, l'enfant d'Yggdrasil tisse autour de lui un épais cocon vert de lianes acides. Lorsque l'empereur des forêts émerge enfin, il est presque affamé et attaque et dévore toute créature qui passe à portée de ses terribles membres noueux.

entries.name: Continually Growing
entries: Les empereurs des forêts ne cessent de grandir, et des spécimens de taille gargantuesque ont été découverts dans les forêts et les montagnes les plus désolées et les plus dangereuses, souvent dans les repaires des dragons qu'ils ont consommés. Des empereurs des forêts exceptionnellement puissants sont même parvenus jusqu'aux racines enchevêtrées de l'Arbre-Monde lui-même, passant leur temps à communier avec les esprits féeriques maléfiques et les terribles serpents dont on dit qu'ils s'enroulent autour de ses branches.

trait.name: Fragrant Aura
entries: L'odorant émet un nuage de phéromones à l'odeur sucrée dans un rayon de 6 mètres autour de lui. Un géant, un humanoïde ou une bête qui commence son tour à l'intérieur de l'aura doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Sagesse {@dc 14} ou être {@condition charmed} pendant 1 minute. La créature peut répéter le jet de sauvegarde à la fin de chacun de ses tours, mettant fin à l'effet sur elle-même en cas de réussite.

Si une créature rate le jet de sauvegarde trois fois en 1 heure, elle est {@condition charmed} pendant 1 jour et obéit aux ordres verbaux ou télépathiques de l'odorant. Si la créature subit des dommages de la part de l'odorant ou de ses alliés ou reçoit un ordre suicidaire, elle peut répéter le jet de sauvegarde, mettant fin à l'effet en cas de réussite.

L'odorant ne peut avoir plus de six créatures charmées à la fois. Le parfumeur peut mettre fin à son charme sur une créature à tout moment (aucune action requise). Si le parfumeur a six créatures {@condition charmed} et qu'une septième créature échoue à son jet de sauvegarde, le parfumeur peut choisir de libérer son charme sur une autre créature pour la remplacer par la nouvelle créature ou pour que la nouvelle créature ne soit pas affectée par l'aura.

trait.name: Strength in Numbers
entries: L'odorant devient plus puissant lorsqu'il a {@condition charmed} d'alliés. Pour chaque {@condition charmed} allié dans un rayon de 6 mètres, le parfumé gagne 5 points de vie temporaires, sa classe d'armure augmente de 1, et il inflige 2 ({@damage 1d4}) de dégâts psychiques supplémentaires lorsqu'il touche avec une attaque. Les points de vie temporaires obtenus grâce à ce trait se reconstituent toutes les 1 minute.

action.name: Phrenic Antennae
entries: {@atk ms} {@hit +6} pour toucher, portée de 1,5 m, une cible. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) dégâts psychiques, et la cible doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Sagesse {@dc 14} ou être {@condition incapacitated} jusqu'à la fin de son prochain tour.

reaction.name: Interpose Ally
entries: Lorsqu'une créature que l'odorant peut voir le cible d'une attaque, l'odorant peut forcer un allié {@condition charmed} dans un rayon de 1,5 mètre de lui à se déplacer entre lui et l'attaque. L'allié {@condition charmed} devient la cible de l'attaque à la place. Si l'allié {@condition charmed} subit des dégâts de cette attaque, il peut immédiatement répéter le jet de sauvegarde de l'Aura parfumée, mettant fin à la condition {@condition charmed} sur lui-même en cas de réussite.

Une créature jaune pâle et verte ressemblant à une limace, avec une expression bénigne sur son visage humain rond, est assise au sommet d'un grand champignon. De longues antennes ondulent au sommet de sa tête chauve tandis que ses yeux bleus langoureux observent son environnement.

entries.name: Fairytale Fey
entries: Un parfumeur est une créature fantaisiste et enjouée dont l'attitude innocente et amicale cache une intelligence rusée. Les parfums se nourrissent de compagnie et utilisent leurs phéromones magiques pour s'introduire dans la vie d'autres créatures, en particulier les humanoïdes des bois et les géants. Étrangement, les parfums ne savent rien de l'engagement réel ou de l'amitié, et toutes leurs relations sont construites sur des mensonges et des tromperies.

entries.name: Safety in Numbers
entries: Les odorants sont relativement faibles lorsqu'ils sont seuls, ayant à peine assez de force pour repousser les prédateurs. En revanche, lorsqu'il est en présence de plusieurs compagnons charmés, il devient beaucoup plus menaçant, son corps se couvre d'épaisses plaques chitineuses et ses antennes s'allongent.

trait.name: Deafening Boom
entries: Quand une créature touche le boomer avec une attaque de mêlée, le boomer libère une explosion sonore. Chaque créature dans un rayon de 3 mètres du boomer qui peut l'entendre doit effectuer un jet de sauvegarde de Constitution {@dc 12}. En cas d'échec, la créature subit 5 ({@damage 2d4}) de dégâts de tonnerre et est {@condition incapacitated} jusqu'à la fin de son prochain tour. En cas de réussite, la créature subit la moitié des dégâts et n'est pas {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Death Burst
entries: Lorsqu'il meurt, le boomer explose dans une rafale cacophonique. Chaque créature dans un rayon de 30 pieds du boomer qui peut l'entendre doit effectuer un jet de sauvegarde de Constitution {@dc 12}. En cas d'échec, la créature subit 7 ({@damage 2d6}) de dégâts de tonnerre et est {@condition deafened} pendant 1 minute. En cas de réussite, la créature subit la moitié des dégâts et n'est pas {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: Si le boomer reste immobile, il est impossible de le distinguer d'un champignon ordinaire.

reaction.name: Shriek
entries: Si une lumière vive ou une créature se trouve à moins de 30 pieds du boomer, celui-ci émet un hurlement audible dans un rayon de 300 pieds. Le boomer continue de hurler jusqu'à ce que la perturbation se mette hors de portée et pendant {@dice 1d4} des tours du boomer par la suite.
Un cri perçant résonne dans la caverne. Le son provient d'un champignon de taille humaine dont le pédoncule se gonfle régulièrement d'air pendant qu'il hurle.

entries.name: Thunderous Shriek
entries: Les boomers sont une sous-espèce de shrieker, presque impossible à distinguer de leurs cousins plus inoffensifs. Lorsqu'il crie, cependant, le pédoncule du boomer se dilate sensiblement, se gonflant d'air jusqu'à ce qu'il libère l'air dans un bruit de tonnerre. Comme son parent plus commun, il est souvent délibérément cultivé par des races souterraines intelligentes comme mesure défensive contre les intrus.

trait.name: Hypnotic Secretion
entries: Lorsqu'une créature commence son tour à moins de 30 pieds du champignon, elle doit effectuer un jet de sauvegarde de Charisme {@dc 15}. En cas d'échec, la créature est {@condition charmed} pendant 1 heure et considère le champignon comme une connaissance amicale. Si le champignon ou l'un de ses alliés fait du mal à la créature charmée, cet effet prend fin. Si une créature reste charmée pendant l'heure complète, elle est infectée par {@disease ophio spores|ToB2}. Si le jet de sauvegarde de la créature est réussi ou si l'effet prend fin pour elle, la créature est immunisée contre la sécrétion hypnotique du champignon ophio pendant les 24 heures suivantes. Une créature qui n'a pas besoin de respirer est immunisée contre la sécrétion hypnotique du champignon. Une créature qui a besoin de respirer peut quand même être affectée, même si elle retient sa respiration.

action.name: Release Spores
entries: Le champignon ophio concentre ses spores sur un maximum de trois créatures qu'il peut voir dans un rayon de 30 pieds autour de lui. Chaque créature doit effectuer un jet de sauvegarde de Constitution {@dc 15}. En cas d'échec, la créature subit 14 ({@damage 4d6}) de dégâts de poison et, si c'est un humanoïde, elle est infectée par {@disease ophio spores|ToB2}. En cas de réussite, la créature subit la moitié des dégâts et n'est pas infectée par les spores. Une créature qui n'a pas besoin de respirer réussit automatiquement ce jet de sauvegarde. Une créature qui a besoin de respirer peut quand même être affectée, même si elle retient sa respiration.
Des rangées et des rangées de champignons violets poussent sur les rochers comme des étagères vivantes. L'air devient brumeux lorsque le champignon émet une soudaine bouffée de spores.

entries.name: Ambitious Parasite
entries: Le champignon ophio est originaire des cavernes souterraines qui serpentent dans Leng, mais il n'a pas l'intention de rester uniquement dans son monde natal. Le champignon cherche à infecter autant de porteurs que possible afin de se distribuer sur de nombreux plans et mondes.

entries.name: Mind Control
entries: Le champignon tente d'infecter les porteurs en émettant des nuages de spores microscopiques. Une fois inhalées, ces spores attaquent le cerveau de la victime, sapant sa volonté et la laissant finalement sous le contrôle du champignon.

entries.name: Master Plan
entries: Une fois qu'une victime est infectée par les spores d'ophio, elle est entièrement sous le contrôle du champignon, reliée au champignon parent par un lien psychique qui traverse même les plans. Le champignon utilise ces victimes pour transporter des morceaux de lui-même vers d'autres endroits ou pour attirer d'autres victimes dans ses cavernes.

entries.name: Ophio Spores
entries: Cette maladie affecte les humanoïdes qui respirent. Les yeux des créatures infectées deviennent vitreux, et des ecchymoses violettes apparaissent sur leur colonne vertébrale, se gonflant au fur et à mesure que la maladie progresse. À la fin de chaque repos long après l'infection, une créature infectée est tourmentée par des rêves ou des visions terribles et doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Constitution {@dc 15} ou subir un niveau de {@condition exhaustion} qui ne peut être supprimé jusqu'à ce que la maladie soit guérie. Après avoir subi deux niveaux de {@condition exhaustion}, la créature passe au deuxième stade de l'infection. Pendant le premier stade de l'infection, un sort de {@spell lesser restoration} ou une magie similaire met fin à l'infection.

À la fin de chaque repos long après que la créature a atteint le deuxième stade de l'infection, elle doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Constitution {@dc 15} ou devenir un esclave du champignon ophio, tombant complètement sous son contrôle. Une victime au deuxième stade de l'infection ou qui est complètement sous le contrôle du champignon ne peut être rétablie qu'en tuant le champignon à l'origine de l'infection ou par l'utilisation d'un sort de {@spell wish}.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: Alors que le parapluie du lutin reste immobile, il est indiscernable d'un champignon ordinaire.

action.name: Twirl
entries: Le parapluie du lutin virevolte, faisant tourner ses spores sur les créatures proches. Chaque créature se trouvant à moins de 1,5 m du parapluie du lutin doit effectuer un jet de sauvegarde de Constitution {@dc 10}, subissant 5 ({@damage 2d4}) dégâts de poison en cas d'échec, ou la moitié des dégâts en cas de réussite. Si le jet de sauvegarde échoue par 5 ou plus, la cible subit également {@condition poisoned} jusqu'à la fin de son prochain tour.

reaction.name: Float
entries: Lorsqu'un parapluie de lutin détecte un mouvement à moins de 30 pieds de lui, il remplit sa coiffe d'air et s'envole à 20 pieds du mouvement sans le provoquer {@action opportunity attack|phb|opportunity attacks}.
Des dizaines de champignons plats, au chapeau violet, flottent et tournent dans l'air.

D'énormes colonies de parapluies de lutins habitent le monde souterrain. Lorsqu'ils sentent un danger, ils remplissent leurs capuchons pour prendre de la hauteur puis relâchent l'air, utilisant les capuchons aplatis pour ralentir leur descente.

entries.name: Migrating Fungus
entries: Leur capacité à flotter leur permet de s'installer sur des surfaces difficiles à atteindre, frustrant ceux qui apprécient la chair amère des champignons. Le sol sous les parapluies de lutin qui habitent les murs et les falaises est parfois jonché des restes squelettiques de voyageurs affamés qui sont tombés dans leurs tentatives désespérées de trouver de la nourriture.

entries.name: Dizzying Drifters
entries: Assister à la migration d'une colonie de parapluies de lutin peut être fascinant pour ceux qui aiment regarder un grand nombre de ces champignons flotter de caverne en caverne. Les chasseurs intelligents du monde souterrain utilisent parfois la migration des parapluies de lutin pour masquer leur approche, comptant sur le spectacle pour distraire leur proie.

trait.name: Shapechanger
entries: Le shiftshroom peut utiliser son action pour modifier son apparence en un champignon plus effrayant, tel qu'un champignon vénéneux à tête de mort, ou reprendre sa vraie forme. Il peut également reprendre sa véritable forme en réaction aux dégâts qu'il subit. Ses statistiques sont les mêmes dans chaque forme, et il retourne à sa vraie forme s'il meurt. Lorsqu'il est sous sa forme effrayante, le shiftshroom ne peut effectuer que les actions {@action Dodge}, {@action Disengage}, et {@action Hide}. Toute créature qui commence son tour à moins de 10 pieds d'un shiftshroom sous sa forme effrayante doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Sagesse {@dc 10} ou être {@condition frightened} du shiftshroom jusqu'au début de son prochain tour. En cas de jet de sauvegarde réussi, la créature est immunisée contre cette caractéristique pendant 24 heures.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +3} pour toucher, portée de 1,5 m, une cible. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d6 + 1}) dégâts de matraquage.
Le simple champignon blanc se transforme soudainement en une tête de mort empoisonnée.

Dans leur forme naturelle, les champignons de Paris sont des champignons blancs aux pieds bifurqués. Leur capacité naturelle à se déguiser en d'autres champignons a évolué pour se défendre contre les créatures qui les récoltent pour se nourrir.

entries.name: Sought for Food
entries: Les champignons de Paris grillés ont une saveur et un arôme de noix et sont considérés comme un mets délicat par de nombreux habitants du monde souterrain. Les gourmets avertis du monde de la surface paient des sommes respectables pour les chapeaux de champignons de Paris en raison de la difficulté de les récolter dans le monde souterrain et de la difficulté de les faire pousser en surface.

entries.name: Hidden in View
entries: On trouve souvent les champignons lents parmi des champignons plus mortels. Le monde souterrain cache des colonies de champignons dont seuls quelques champignons situés aux extrémités du groupe sont des variétés dangereuses de champignons, les autres étant des champignons lents déguisés.

trait.name: Strobe
entries: Comme action bonus, le champignon stroboscopique peut commencer à émettre une lumière puissante et stroboscopique. Il alterne rapidement entre l'émission d'une lumière vive dans un rayon de 60 pieds et l'absence de lumière, créant un effet de vertige, sauf si la lumière ambiante de la zone est une lumière vive.

Chaque créature située à moins de 60 pieds du champignon stroboscopique et qui peut voir la lumière doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Constitution {@dc 14} ou être {@condition blinded} pendant 1 minute. Une créature {@condition blinded} peut répéter le jet de sauvegarde à la fin de chacun de ses tours, mettant fin à l'effet sur elle-même en cas de réussite.

À moins d'être surprise, une créature possédant un {@item shield|phb} ou un autre objet de taille similaire peut utiliser sa réaction pour soulever l'objet et protéger ses yeux de la lumière, en évitant le jet de sauvegarde. Si elle le fait, elle ne peut pas utiliser cet objet pour autre chose. Par exemple, une créature utilisant un {@item shield|phb} pour se protéger les yeux perd le bonus de {@item shield|phb} à sa classe d'armure lorsqu'elle utilise le {@item shield|phb} de cette façon. Si la créature regarde le champignon stroboscopique ou abaisse ou utilise l'objet protégeant ses yeux, elle doit immédiatement effectuer la sauvegarde.
Pendant qu'il émet de la lumière, le champignon stroboscopique ne peut pas attaquer. Il peut arrêter d'émettre de la lumière à tout moment (aucune action requise).

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Le champignon stroboscopique fait deux attaques.

action.name: Chemical Burn
entries: {@atk mw|rw} {@hit +5} pour toucher, portée de 5 ft. ou portée de 30/120 ft., une créature. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) dégâts d'acide.

Cette créature est translucide avec un noyau blanc et se compose d'une tige étroite surmontée d'une tête bulbeuse. Elle émet soudain une puissante lumière vive, puis des éclairs lumineux et sombres en succession rapide.

entries.name: Chemical Warrior
entries: Le corps du champignon stroboscopique contient des substances chimiques qui, lorsqu'elles sont mélangées, le font briller plus fort qu'une torche. Il utilise également ces produits chimiques pour se défendre. Lorsqu'il sent un danger, il mélange les produits chimiques dans une poche à l'intérieur de son corps et sécrète le mélange, qu'il peut ensuite tirer sur la créature qui le menace. Une fois exposés à l'air libre, les produits chimiques deviennent très corrosifs et toxiques.

entries.name: Wandering Mushroom
entries: Contrairement à de nombreux champignons, le champignon stroboscopique est capable de se déplacer, bien qu'à un rythme lent. Pour ce faire, il coupe la partie de sa base qui l'ancre en place et sécrète certains produits chimiques dans son corps pour l'aider à glisser vers un nouvel endroit. Lorsqu'il a atteint sa destination, il cesse de sécréter la substance chimique, son mouvement s'arrête et la créature se fixe rapidement au sol au nouvel endroit.

entries.name: Popular Guards
entries: Les champignons stroboscopiques sont souvent employés comme gardiens, en particulier par les créatures qui ont {@sense blindsight}. Les champignons comprennent le commun rudimentaire et peuvent obéir aux ordres de ne pas attaquer les alliés de leur maître. Ils considèrent généralement que toute personne qui ne leur a pas été spécifiquement présentée est un ennemi et se comportent en conséquence.

trait.name: Aura of Lassitude
entries: Une créature qui commence son tour à moins de 30 pieds du galidroo doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Constitution {@dc 17} ou se sentir léthargique jusqu'au début de son prochain tour. Lorsqu'elle est léthargique, la créature ne peut pas utiliser de réactions, sa vitesse est réduite de moitié et elle ne peut pas effectuer plus d'une attaque de mêlée ou à distance à son tour. De plus, la créature peut utiliser soit une action, soit une action bonus à son tour, mais pas les deux. En cas de jet de sauvegarde réussi, la créature est immunisée contre l'Aura de lassitude du galidroo pendant les 24 heures suivantes.

trait.name: Selective Precognition
entries: Le galidroo peut voir dans le passé, le présent et le futur simultanément. Il peut lancer de manière innée {@spell divination} et {@spell legend lore} une fois par jour chacun, ne nécessitant aucun composant matériel. Sa capacité innée de lanceur de sorts est la Sagesse. Le galidroo ne peut pas utiliser ces sorts pour obtenir des informations sur lui-même ou sur son futur ou passé personnel.

trait.name: Two-Headed
entries: Le galidroo a un avantage sur les tests de Sagesse ({@skill Perception}) et sur les jets de sauvegarde contre le fait d'être {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, et frappé {@condition unconscious}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Le galidroo effectue quatre attaques : deux avec sa morsure et deux avec ses griffes. Il peut faire une attaque de queue à la place de ses deux attaques de griffes.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} pour toucher, portée de 10 ft., une cible. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) dégâts perforants.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} pour toucher, portée de 1,5 m, une cible. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) dégâts tranchants.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} pour toucher, portée de 15 ft, une cible. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) de dégâts de matraquage. La cible est {@condition grappled} (s'échapper {@dc 17}) si elle est une créature Large ou plus petite et que le galidroo n'a pas une autre créature {@condition grappled}. Jusqu'à la fin de ce grappin, la cible est {@condition restrained}, et le galidroo ne peut pas utiliser sa queue sur une autre cible.

action.name: Prophetic Screech {@recharge 5}
entries: Le galidroo libère une rafale de pouvoir prophétique dans un cône de 60 pieds. Chaque créature dans cette zone doit effectuer un jet de sauvegarde d'Intelligence {@dc 17}. En cas d'échec, la créature subit 35 ({@damage 10d6}) de dégâts psychiques et est {@condition incapacitated} pendant 1 minute tandis que son esprit est bombardé de visions de son passé et de son avenir. En cas de réussite, la créature subit la moitié des dégâts et n'est pas {@condition incapacitated}. La créature peut répéter le jet de sauvegarde à la fin de chacun de ses tours, mettant fin à l'effet sur elle-même en cas de réussite.

Cette horrible créature est plus grande qu'un bœuf, et sa peau glabre et ridée est couverte de verrues et de pustules répugnantes. La créature possède deux têtes semblables à celles des rats et une lourde queue tentaculaire qui fouette l'air de façon malveillante.

entries.name: Wasteland Monstrosity
entries: Le galidroo habite principalement les badlands désolés, les ruines ravagées et les zones où la magie a corrompu le paysage et les créatures qui s'y trouvent. Bien qu'ils soient des monstres puissants, ils sont rarement au sommet de la chaîne alimentaire et doivent se méfier d'autres monstres comme les {@creature purple worm|mm|purple worms} et les {@creature ancient wasteland dragon|CCodex|wasteland dragons} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}).

entries.name: Prophetic Beasts
entries: Les deux têtes du galidroo peuvent voir simultanément le passé, le présent et l'avenir, ce qui lui donne une vision déformée et presque fataliste de la vie. Puisque le galidroo ne peut pas voir son propre passé ou son propre avenir, il est rempli d'une frustration sans fin, et il déchaîne sa rage sur tous ceux qui ont la malchance de croiser son chemin. De puissantes liches réduisent souvent les galidroos en esclavage, forçant les créatures à utiliser leurs talents de prophètes pour servir les plans des liches. En raison du mauvais traitement qu'ils reçoivent généralement, les galidroos se retournent rapidement contre leurs "maîtres".

trait.name: Plant Camouflage
entries: L'ail a l'avantage sur les tests de Dextérité ({@skill Stealth}) qu'il effectue dans tout terrain où il y a beaucoup de vie végétale obscurcissante.

trait.name: Tearful Stench
entries: Chaque créature autre qu'un {@creature alliumite|CCodex} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}) ou un ail dans un rayon de 1,5 mètre de l'ail lorsqu'il subit des dégâts doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Constitution {@dc 14} ou être {@condition blinded} jusqu'au début du prochain tour de la créature. En cas de jet de sauvegarde réussi, la créature est immunisée contre la puanteur déchirante de tous les {@creature alliumite|CCodex|alliumites} et les aulx pendant 1 minute.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: La capacité innée de lanceur de sorts de l'ail est la Sagesse (sauvegarde contre les sorts {@dc 14}). Il peut lancer de manière innée les sorts suivants, ne nécessitant aucun composant matériel :

action.name: Walking Staff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +0} pour toucher ({@hit 6} pour toucher avec {@spell shillelagh}), portée de 5 ft, une cible. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d6 - 2}) dégâts de matraquage, 2 ({@damage 1d8 - 2}) dégâts de matraquage si manié à deux mains, ou 8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) dégâts de matraquage avec {@spell shillelagh}.

action.name: Cloves of Fate {@recharge 4}
entries: L'aïoli arrache des gousses de sa tête et les lance sur un maximum de trois créatures qu'il peut voir dans un rayon de 30 pieds autour de lui. Lancez un {@dice d4} pour chaque créature. Les alliés de l'ail ont +1 sur le jet tandis que ses ennemis ont -1 sur le jet. Déterminez le résultat et consultez la table suivante.

colLabels: {@dice d4 + 1|d4 + 1|Cloves of Fate (Ally)} / {@dice d4 - 1|d4 - 1|Cloves of Fate (Enemies)}

rows.name: Worst Fortune
entries: Ce que la cible tient dans ses mains glisse dans un espace aléatoire situé à moins de 1,5 m de la cible, et la cible tombe {@condition prone} en trébuchant sur un rocher, de l'herbe mouillée par la pluie, ses lacets ou autre.

rows.name: Bad Fortune
entries: La cible subit 10 ({@damage 3d6}) de dégâts de poison et doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de Constitution {@dc 14} ou être {@condition poisoned} jusqu'à la fin de son prochain tour.

rows.name: Adverse Fortune
entries: La cible a un désavantage sur son prochain jet d'attaque.

rows.name: Favorable Fortune
entries: La cible a l'avantage sur son prochain jet d'attaque.

rows.name: Good Fortune
entries: La cible regagne 5 ({@dice 2d4}) pv.

rows.name: Best Fortune
entries: Le prochain coup réussi de la cible est critique.

La créature feuillue chante en interprétant un présage dans une colonne de fumée âcre et grondante. La petite créature crie "Malheur !" en pointant un doigt noueux, signalant aux autres créatures feuillues de se lever avec des armes prêtes à l'emploi.

entries.name: Trusted Seers
entries: Dans les jardins des {@creature alliumite|CCodex|alliumites} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}), les anciens alliumites pratiquent la magie divinatoire pour guider et protéger leurs communautés. Surnommés les "ailés" par leur communauté, ces anciens utilisent des clous de girofle arrachés de leur propre tête pour prédire l'avenir, les lançant comme les osselets d'un augure. La magie féerique résiduelle qui infuse tous les alliumites provoque parfois des résultats étranges dans les prédictions d'un aïeul.

entries.name: Wisdom Sought, Rarely Given
entries: Les personnes désespérées recherchent souvent les aulx, en quête de réponses à des questions telles que les prévisions météorologiques, les reliques perdues et les destins cachés. Ces efforts sont souvent vains, car les alliumites refusent la plupart des pétitionnaires. Seuls ceux qui gagnent le titre d'"ami du jardin" ont droit à une audience. Souvent, les courroucés se vengent d'avoir été rejetés, mais les ailés sages sont prompts à négocier la paix ou, à défaut, à préparer une défense appropriée.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: L'homme décharné a un avantage sur les tests de sagesse ({@skill Perception}) qui font appel à l'ouïe.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Le gaunt one effectue deux attaques de griffes. Si les deux attaques touchent une cible de taille moyenne ou plus petite, celle-ci est {@condition grappled} (échappatoire {@dc 14}).

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} pour toucher, portée de 1,5 m, une créature. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) dégâts tranchants.

action.name: Extract Heart
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} pour toucher, portée de 1,5 m, un humanoïde {@condition grappled} par le gaunt one. {@h}La cible doit réussir un jet de sauvegarde de {@dc 13} Constitution, subissant 22 ({@damage 5d8}) dégâts perforants en cas d'échec, ou la moitié des dégâts en cas de réussite. Si ces dégâts réduisent la cible à 0 pv, le gaunt one la tue en extrayant et en dévorant son cœur.
This corpse-like creature's flesh is gray, its body is emaciated, and its skin is pulled tight across its skeleton. A strange, writhing tentacle protrudes slightly from its gaping mouth.

entries.name: Unnatural Origin
entries: Centuries ago, an order of wizards, known as the Covenant of Infinum, found itself in need of slaves and descended upon a nearby human settlement. The order enslaved every villager and conducted magical experiments upon them in the wizards' remote mountain tower. The wizards were trying to create the perfect servitor race, using the villagers as a baser life form. The experiment failed spectacularly, unleashing a magical transformative wave upon the tower. Many of the wizards managed to escape, but all of the human slaves were caught in the magical chaos and were forever changed into gaunt ones.

entries.name: Undead Appearance
entries: At first glance, gaunt ones appear to be some form of undead creature, leading many to underestimate them. Their skin is pale, shrunken, and withered, and their teeth are yellow and jagged with receded gums.

entries.name: Hunger for Hearts
entries: Gaunt ones have an inherent hunger for hearts and often sit quietly for hours, listening for the heartbeats of nearby creatures. A gaunt one grabs hold of its prey and worms its tentacle-like tongue into the creature's mouth to extract the creature's heart. Insatiable, a gaunt one continues to eat the hearts of creatures it finds until there is nothing left to harvest. Lacking readily available food, it moves on.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The greater ghast of Leng has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hp.

trait.name: Command Ghasts of Leng
entries: As a bonus action, the greater ghast of Leng commands a ghast of Leng within 30 feet of it to make one attack as a reaction against a creature the greater ghast attacked this round.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The greater ghast of Leng has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Sunlight Hypersensitivity
entries: The greater ghast of Leng takes 20 radiant damage when it starts its turn in sunlight. While in sunlight, it has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The greater ghast of Leng makes three attacks: one with its bite and two with its claws. If both claw attacks hit a Medium or smaller target, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, the greater ghast can automatically hit the target with its claws, and the greater ghast can't make claw attacks against other targets.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage.

The creature has a maddened expression on its almost featureless face. Its vaguely humanoid body is covered in lumpy, grayishgreen skin, and its head sits on a long neck. Its long arms end in vicious claws, and it stands on sharp hooves.

entries.name: Leaders of Carnivores
entries: {@creature ghast of leng|CCodex|Ghasts of Leng} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}) who claw their way up, surviving rounds of feeding frenzies, become greater ghasts. They are stronger, tougher, and usually taller than their peers, who look to them for leadership. The greater ghasts of Leng do not, however, provide structured leadership. Instead, they chaotically direct flow of their hungry kin, pointing out prey and keeping the lesser ghasts in line. They are, in essence, the biggest bullies in a pack of scavenger bullies.

trait.name: Forest Camouflage
entries: The ghillie dubh has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in forest terrain.

trait.name: One with the Trees
entries: If the ghillie dubh has spent at least 24 hours in a forest, it has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks while in that forest. In addition, it can spend 10 minutes focusing its attention on the forest and an invisible, sapling-shaped sensor anywhere in its forest within 1 mile of it. It can see and hear everything within 60 feet of this sensor, but it is {@condition deafened|phb|deaf} and {@condition blinded|phb|blind} with regard to its own senses while doing so. The sensor lasts for 1 minute or until the ghillie dubh dismisses it (no action required).

trait.name: Speak with Beasts and Plants
entries: The ghillie dubh can communicate with beasts and plants as if they shared a language.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Forest Knowledge {@recharge 6}
entries: The ghillie dubh can alter nearby creatures' knowledge of the forest, choosing one of the following. An effect lasts for 24 hours, until the creature leaves the ghillie dubh's forest, or until the ghillie dubh dismisses it as a bonus action.

items.name: Remove Knowledge
items.entry: Each creature within 30 feet of the ghillie dubh must succeed on a {@dc 13} Charisma saving throw or become hopelessly lost in the ghillie dubh's forest. The creature has disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks and takes 50 percent more time on overland travel, even delaying clearheaded companions.

items.name: Share Knowledge
items.entry: Each creature within 30 feet of the ghillie dubh has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks. The creature can move at a fast pace through forest terrain, and difficult terrain composed of nonmagical plants doesn't cost it extra movement.

entries: This bipedal creature seems to be a humanoid-shaped mound of leaves and moss given life. Dark pits in its head resemble empty eye sockets.

entries.name: Protectors of the Lost
entries: Ghillie dubhs hail from goodaligned arboreal planes. There, they guide visitors through the sometimes-confounding landscape. They often rescue those who incidentally succumb to the peaceful nature of planar woodlands and might otherwise perish. However, they find their services more useful on the Material Plane where nature is generally more unforgiving. Their desire to help mortals leads them to more extreme climates, with a strong preference for colder weather. Ghillie dubhs find lost travelers and guide these unfortunates to safe places. If a traveler impresses a ghillie dubh with knowledge or a desire for knowledge about the forest, the ghillie dubh gifts the traveler with some of its knowledge.

entries.name: Punishment of Transgression
entries: Likewise, a ghillie dubh expects visitors to the area it oversees to be respectful of the land. Ghillie dubhs lecture mild violators and briefly use nature to inconvenience them, such as by covering paths or removing tracks. More heinous acts—like wantonly slaughtering animals or setting trees ablaze—are met with physical retaliation.

entries.name: Part of the Forest
entries: Ghillie dubhs take on characteristics of the forests they call home to blend in seamlessly with the trees and other plants. They can listen to subtle variations in the trees' movements to receive early warning about attacks, and they can turn their attention to any part of the forest to ensure no harm is coming to an area.

trait.name: Turning Defiance
entries: The bloated ghoul and any ghouls within 30 feet of it have advantage on saving throws against effects that turn undead.

trait.name: Unholy Stench
entries: When the bloated ghoul takes piercing or slashing damage, noxious vapors burst from its distended stomach. Each creature within 10 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage and be {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bloated ghoul makes one bite attack and one claw attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d8 + 3}) piercing damage, and, if the target is a humanoid, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or contract {@disease darakhul fever|ToB2}.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 3d6 + 3}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature other than an undead, it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or have its speed halved and have disadvantage on Dexterity-based checks and saving throws for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Hideous Feast
entries: The bloated ghoul feeds on a corpse within 5 feet of it that is less than 1 week old. It regains {@dice 1d8} hit points per size category of the creature it consumes. For example, the ghoul regains {@dice 1d8} hit points when consuming a Tiny creature or {@dice 4d8} hit points when consuming a Large creature. The bloated ghoul can't use Hideous Feast on a corpse if it or another bloated ghoul has already used Hideous Feast on the corpse.

Bloated ghouls are ghouls who have engaged in ritual gorging on the flesh of hundreds of humanoids, their bodies swelling with undigested meat and bone. They eventually become pot-bellied undead maddened with hunger. A bloated ghoul's home is often slick with spilled blood and guts, which it happily licks off the floor and walls.

entries.name: Hungry Dead Nature
entries: The ghoul doesn't require air or sleep.

trait.name: Master of Disguise
entries: A darakhul in a prepared disguise has advantage on Charisma ({@skill Deception}) checks made to pass as a living creature. While using this ability, it loses its Stench.

trait.name: Necrotic Weapons
entries: The darakhul captain's weapon attacks are magical. When the captain hits with any weapon, the weapon deals an extra {@damage 2d6} necrotic damage (included in the attack).

trait.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of the darakhul must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the darakhul's Stench for 24 hours.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the darakhul has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Turning Defiance
entries: The darakhul and any ghouls within 30 feet of it have advantage on saving throws against effects that turn undead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The darakhul captain makes three attacks: one with its bite, one with its claw, and one with its longsword. Alternatively, it can make four attacks with its longsword.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage. If the target is a humanoid, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or contract {@disease darakhul fever|ToB2}.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage. If the target is a creature other than an undead, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a humanoid is {@condition paralyzed} for more than 2 rounds, it contracts {@disease darakhul fever|ToB2}.

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) slashing damage, or 9 ({@damage 1d10 + 4}) slashing damage if used with two hands, plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Heavy Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +7} to hit, range 100/400 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d10 + 3}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Imperial Conscription {@recharge 6}
entries: The darakhul captain targets one {@condition incapacitated} creature it can see within 30 feet. The target must make a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw, taking 27 ({@damage 5d10}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The target's hp maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the damage taken. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. If the victim has {@disease darakhul fever|ToB2}, this reduction can't be removed until the victim recovers from the disease. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0. A humanoid slain by this attack rises as a {@creature ghast} {@dice 1d4} hours later under the darakhul captain's control, unless the humanoid is restored to life or its body is destroyed. The captain can have no more than four {@creature ghast|mm|ghasts} under its control at one time.

action.name: Leadership (Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: For 1 minute, the darakhul captain can utter a special command or warning whenever a nonhostile creature that it can see within 30 feet of it makes an attack roll or a saving throw. The creature can add a {@dice d4} to its roll provided it can hear and understand the captain. A creature can benefit from only one Leadership die at a time. This effect ends if the captain is {@condition incapacitated}.
Leaders of law enforcement units in undead cities, darakhul captains are stoic and steely darakhul hand-selected by the city's leadership for the role.

entries.name: Patrol Teams
entries: When on patrol, darakhul captains ride {@creature ghoulsteed|ccodex|ghoulsteeds} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press;  and are rarely without a handful of darakhul and ghouls at their sides. In the larger cities, captains patrol with one or two {@creature emperor's hyena|ToB2|emperor's hyenas}.

entries.name: Dangerous Position
entries: Many captains meet their ends not from threats outside the city but from forces within it. Captains regularly face the dangers of being assassinated by a rival or killed by a city leader upset about recent events.

entries.name: Hungry Dead Nature
entries: The darakhul doesn't require air or sleep.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the darakhul spy is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, it instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Master of Disguise
entries: A darakhul in a prepared disguise has advantage on Charisma ({@skill Deception}) checks made to pass as a living creature. While using this ability, it loses its Stench.

trait.name: Sneak Attack (1/Turn)
entries: The darakhul spy deals an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage when it hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of the darakhul spy that isn't incapacitated and the darakhul doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

trait.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of the darakhul must make a successful {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the darakhul's Stench for the next 24 hours. A darakhul using this ability can't also benefit from Master of Disguise.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the darakhul has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Turning Defiance
entries: The darakhul and any ghouls within 30 feet of it have advantage on saving throws against effects that turn undead.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The darakhul makes three attacks: one with its bite, one with its claw, and one with its shortsword.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage, and, if the target creature is humanoid, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or contract {@disease darakhul fever|ToB2}.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature other than an undead, it must make a successful {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a humanoid creature is {@condition paralyzed} for more than 2 rounds, it contracts {@disease darakhul fever|ToB2}.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Light Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +7} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 4}) piercing damage.
The eyes and ears of undead armies, darakhul spies originate from all nations and backgrounds.

entries.name: Masters of Disguise
entries: Darakhul spies are rarely without a slew of disguises, including wigs, colored pastes, cosmetics, and clothing appropriate for various nationalities and economic levels. Some of the best spies have spent decades hiding in plain sight in courts, taverns, and slums across the world.

entries.name: Complex Network
entries: Each spy has one superior to whom it reports, and each superior spy has a separate superior spy to whom it reports. Only the highest leaders have knowledge of the intricacies of the spy network, and even they aren't fully aware of the true identities of their furthest-reaching agents.

entries.name: Hungry Dead Nature
entries: The darakhul doesn't require air or sleep.

trait.name: Paralyzing Throes
entries: When the ghul dies, it explodes in a puff of noxious smoke. Each creature within 5 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its next turn.

trait.name: Turn Resistance
entries: The ghul has advantage on saving throws against any effect that turns undead.

trait.name: Variable Immunity
entries: As a bonus action, the ghul changes one of its damage resistances to immunity to that type of damage until the start of its next turn.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The ghul's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (spell save {@dc 13}, {@hit 5} to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
footerEntries: {@color *if using the {@i Midgard Heroes Handbook}, replace the indicated spells with {@i rolling thunder}, {@i spire of stone}, and {@i frozen razors}, respectively|777}

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The ghul makes two attacks with its claws

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) slashing damage. If the target is a creature other than an elf or undead, it must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

A creature wearing a black turban steps out of the sudden fog. It is roughly the size and shape of a short man, with gray skin and pointed teeth. The thing sneers as it summons lightning to its hand, the air suddenly stinking of ozone. Its stony gray skin shifts to an icy blue as it raises its arm to direct its electrical attack.

entries.name: Elemental Remnants
entries: When an undead with the ability to raise more of their kind, such as a {@creature vampire}, {@creature wight}, or {@creature wraith}, slays a geniekin or other lesser elemental, the risen creature is a ghul instead. Rather than retaining control of whatever elemental forces it may have had during its life, the ghul becomes representative of all four of the classical elements.

entries.name: Unyielding Hunger
entries: Like more common {@creature ghoul|mm|ghouls} and {@creature ghast|mm|ghasts}, a ghul's existence is focused around a relentless, agonizing need to consume living flesh. Ghuls favor live targets and can be seen sampling their meal even while battle rages around them. Despite their substantial innate magical ability, some ghuls prefer to rend with their claws, reveling in the tearing of flesh and the sensation of hot blood dripping from their cold bodies.

entries.name: Royal Aspirations
entries: Ghuls evolve over the centuries, gaining power and a semblance of their original personality, now twisted by countless evil acts. Their slow personal growth leads most ghuls to a craven existence, striking from the shadows and using their magic to flee if their prey puts up too much of a fight. If a ghul survives long enough, it gains enough power to be grudgingly acknowledged by lesser ghuls. These greater ghuls are often called "ghul kings" by those who encounter them, as the greater ghuls often create a semblance of a "royal court" out of lesser ghuls and other undead.

entries.name: Hungry Dead Nature
entries: The ghul doesn't require air or sleep.

trait.name: One with the Earth
entries: The abbanith giant can detect the flows and rhythms of the earth—including things that interfere with these rhythms, such as earthquakes and magical anomalies. As a result, the abbanith giant can't be surprised by an opponent that is touching the ground. In addition, the giant has advantage on attack rolls against constructs and elementals made of earth or stone.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The giant deals double damage to objects and structures and triple damage to objects and structures made of earth or stone.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The abbanith giant makes two thumb claw attacks.

action.name: Thumb Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Earth Counter {@recharge 6}
entries: When a creature the abbanith can see within 30 feet of it casts a spell, the abbanith counters it. This reaction works like the {@spell counterspell} spell, except the abbanith can only counter spells that directly affect or create earth or stone, such as {@spell stone shape}, {@spell wall of stone}, or {@spell move earth}, and it doesn't need to make a spellcasting ability check, regardless of the spell's level.
This giant has a bulky, muscular body and small eyes in its broad, flat face. The giant's thumbs end in large, black claws.

entries.name: Ancient Giants of the Deep
entries: Abbanith giants are among the oldest races of giants known to exist and are said to have been around since the world was first formed. Many scholars turn to the giants' deep connection with the earth as evidence of this fact, and the giants themselves make no efforts to deny it. Indeed, the oral tradition of the abbanith giants dates back millennia, to a time when gods walked the land, elves were first learning the secrets of magic, and humans were still living in caves. Most abbanith giants wear simple tunics or shorts woven of a strange subterranean fungus, though leaders occasionally wear armor.

entries.name: Consummate Diggers
entries: Abbanith giants dwell almost exclusively underground and are adept at using their incredibly hard thumb claws to dig massive tunnels through the earth. Druids and wizards studying the giants' unique biology have deduced that mineral-based materials actually soften when struck by their claws. This feature has also made them the target of {@creature derro|mtf} and {@creature duergar} slavers wishing to use their skills to mine precious gems or build their fortifications, something the giants violently oppose despite their normally peaceable nature.

entries.name: Allies of the Earth
entries: For as long as either race can remember, abbanith giants have been allies of the pech, the two races sharing a passion for all things earth and stone. Families of abbanith giants frequently live with pech colonies, the abbanith giants harvesting the stone the pech work and the two races sharing in the defense of the community. Abbanith giants defer to their smaller pech friends in most matters of importance, and many outsiders view the fondness and attentiveness that the much larger giants have for their stony friends with bemusement.

trait.name: Sunlight Petrification
entries: If the cave giant shaman starts its turn in sunlight, it takes 20 radiant damage. While in sunlight, it moves at half speed and has disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks. If the giant is reduced to 0 hp while in sunlight, it is {@condition petrified}.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The cave giant shaman is a 14th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Charisma (save {@dc 18}, {@hit 10} to hit with spell attacks). The shaman has the following wizard spells prepared:

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The cave giant shaman makes two attacks: one with its club and one with its tusks.

action.name: Club
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d4 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Tusks
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 4d6 + 8}) slashing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 20} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +13} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one creature. {@h}30 ({@damage 4d10 + 8}) bludgeoning damage.

This massive, bipedal creature has a slight hunch, making its long arms appear even longer. It wields a massive club etched with sigils. A pair of yellow tusks, adorned with rings of all materials, protrudes from its lower jaw.

Cave giant shamans are gifted spellcasters who believe they are suited to consume spellcasting humanoids and absorb the humanoids' power. While the truth to this claim is dubious, there is no doubting their arcane prowess. They gravitate toward magic that allows them to change the composition of all materials, including air, flesh, and stone.

entries.name: Practical Leader
entries: Cave giant shamans are less superstitious than lesser {@creature cave giant|ccodex|cave giants} ({@loader Creature Codex|collection/Kobold Press; Creature Codex.json}) and have learned to employ superstitions as a weapon to maintain power or convince the giants to do something they may not otherwise wish to do. Despite their more practical approaches to the world around them, cave giant shamans still jealously hoard the flesh of known spellcasters to sustain or enhance their power.

trait.name: Ethereal Jaunt
entries: As a bonus action, the phase giant can magically shift from the Material Plane to the Ethereal Plane, or vice versa. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying shifts with it. A creature grappled by the phase giant doesn't shift with it, and the grapple ends if the phase giant shifts while grappling a creature.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two attacks with its spiked fists. If both attacks hit a Large or smaller target, the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) piercing damage as the giant impales the target on its body spikes.

action.name: Spiked Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage. If the target is a Large or smaller creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). The phase giant has two fists, each of which can grapple only one target.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +8} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.
This immense humanoid is covered in dark, spiny, chitinous skin, and its sizeable fists are rough and decorated with sharp spikes.

entries.name: Natural Carapace
entries: The phase giant has naturally hard skin, similar to that of a giant insect. Its face, hands, and joints are articulated and overlapping, allowing it to move freely beneath its hardened skin. The carapace grows into spikes in numerous places throughout its body, which it uses against captured prey and to aid it in climbing.

entries.name: Highly Mobile
entries: Deep caverns can be difficult to navigate with their twists and tight squeezes. The phase giant overcomes this by sliding into the Ethereal Plane and passing through the solid stone.

entries.name: Familial
entries: Phase giants are smaller than the average hill giant, but they more than make up for it in their ferocity. They are aggressive toward others, but not actually evil, tending to view most they encounter as mere annoyances. They are usually found in small family units of up to four, but rarely band together in larger groups.

trait.name: Blacklight Strobe
entries: The visual flicker of the shadow giant moving between the Material Plane and the Shadow Realm has a physical effect on viewers. A creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the shadow giant and that can see it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Wisdom saving throw or be unable make more than one melee or ranged attack on its turn and unable to use bonus actions or reactions until the start of its next turn.

trait.name: Distracting Flicker
entries: A creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of the shadow giant and that is maintaining concentration on a spell must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or lose concentration.

trait.name: Shadow Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the shadow giant's {@sense darkvision}.

trait.name: Umbral Glimmer
entries: At the end of each of the shadow giant's turns, it must roll a {@dice d20}. On a roll of 11 or higher, it enters the Plane of Shadow from the Material Plane. At the start of its next turn, it returns to the Material Plane in an unoccupied space of its choice that it can see within 40 feet of the space where it vanished. If no unoccupied space is available within that range, it appears in the nearest unoccupied space.
While in the Plane of Shadow, the shadow giant can see and hear 120 feet into the Material Plane. It can't affect or be affected by anything on the Material Plane while in the Plane of Shadow.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shadow giant makes three attacks with its tenebrous talons.

action.name: Tenebrous Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +12} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d6 + 7}) slashing damage plus 18 ({@damage 4d8}) necrotic damage.

action.name: Cold Shadow {@recharge 5}
entries: The shadow giant directs its shadow to stretch out in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 52 ({@damage 15d6}) cold damage and has disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws until the end of its next turn. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and doesn't have disadvantage.
If not for the horns curling from its brow and the long, bestial talons erupting from its fingers, the creature would look like a grim-faced, ashen-skinned elf of monstrous height.

entries.name: Cast into Darkness
entries: In ages past, shadow giants were called hjartakinde, and they dwelt in the lands of the fey. When the giants declined to go to war with the shadow fey, the fey exiled them to the Shadow Realm. When they refused to serve the dark fey courts, the queen cursed them into their current form.

entries.name: Of Two Worlds
entries: Shadow giants are cursed to exist simultaneously on the Shadow Realm and the Material Plane. Unable to properly live in either world, they have become embittered and indignant. Shadow giants desire to end their cursed existence but lash out against anyone who shows them pity or mercy.

entries.name: Undying
entries: When a shadow giant is killed, its spirit roils in the Shadow Realm for a century before it is reborn to its cursed fate.

trait.name: Snow Camouflage
entries: The snow giant has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in snowy terrain.

trait.name: Snow Regeneration
entries: The snow giant regains 5 hp at the start of its turn if it has at least 1 hp and it is in snowy terrain.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The snow giant makes two club attacks.

action.name: Club
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 3d4 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Giant Snowball
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +7} to hit, range 60/240 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage plus 4 ({@damage 1d8}) cold damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 16} Dexterity save or be {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.
Flurries drift from the body of this gigantic humanoid seemingly crafted from snow. Its simple clothes are almost pointless, and it carries a massive icicle as a club.

entries.name: Subservient to Frost Giants
entries: Snow giants inhabit the same territory as {@creature frost giant|mm|frost giants}, but they are considerably smaller than their more aggressive kin. Snow giants offer themselves up as servants to frost giants, most likely as a survival mechanism. The larger giants often employ snow giants as menial domestic servants, forcing them to clean lairs or craft armor and weapons. Frost giants view snow giants as incompetent at waging war, but they send the lesser giants as a vanguard against foes they suspect will prove tougher than their own numbers can handle. The bigger giants also use snow giants as proxies to settle clan disputes or questions of leadership.

Despite the bullying and maltreatment they receive from frost giants, snow giants rarely consider rebelling against their more powerful cousins. They often take the long view that their lives would be worse without the frost giants' protection.

entries.name: Inherently Playful Beings
entries: If snow giants had their druthers and managed to avoid sharing space with frost giants, they would be more concerned with enjoying the wintry landscape they inhabit. When not driven by frost giants or by the need to acquire food, snow giants are mirthful and enjoy getting into snowball fights with those they encounter. Among themselves, these snowball fights are akin to children playing in the snow. They are unaware of their own strength when engaging in such activity with smaller beings. The giants quickly realize the harm they inflict, and, provided they don't receive armed retaliation for the accidental injuries they cause, they apologize and revert to using considerably smaller and less impactful snowballs.

entries.name: Snowy Flesh
entries: As most giants are at least touched by primal elements, so too are snow giants partially composed of the element of water, at least in its frozen form. While this offers them considerably less protection than a stone giant's granite flesh, their connection to snow allows them to heal themselves merely by applying a patch of snow to an injury. Packing on snow also allows the snow giants to hide themselves more effectively, which becomes useful when they attempt to avoid the notice of brutal frost giants.

trait.name: Contortionist
entries: The thin giant can contort its body into unnatural positions, allowing it to easily move through any opening large enough for a Medium creature. It can squeeze through any opening large enough for a Small creature. The giant's destination must still have suitable room to accommodate its volume.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The thin giant makes three melee attacks, but it can use its Consuming Bite only once.

action.name: Consuming Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d8 + 6}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage. The target's hp maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the necrotic damage taken, and the giant regains hp equal to that amount. This reduction lasts until the target finishes a long rest. The target dies if this effect reduces its hp maximum to 0.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) slashing damage.

This tall, emaciated giant has unnaturally long arms ending in razor-sharp talons. It has a strangely conical head with glowing red eyes and fearsome fangs. Its skin is a dark gray-green, and its body is completely devoid of hair.

entries.name: Giant Bogeymen
entries: Lurking in abandoned mansions, dark wells, ancient mine shafts, and similar locations, thin giants are one of the most sinister and frightening of all giant species. The villains of many children's nightmares, thin giants are feared even by other giants, as their life-draining bite and ability to get into tight spaces make them unsettling at best and horrifying at worst. Thin giants don't get along with most creatures, but they have been observed leading groups of {@creature ghoul|mm|ghouls}, {@creature ettercap|mm|ettercaps}, and {@creature troll|mm|trolls} to capture and devour prey.

entries.name: Contortion Experts
entries: Thin giants have remarkable control over their bodies. They can twist their limbs into unnatural positions and even bend completely double. The flexibility and elasticity help the giants shrug off crushing blows. They can stay in contorted positions for extraordinary lengths of time and use this to their advantage to ambush unsuspecting creatures.

monster.name: Glacial Corrupter
languages: understands all languages it knew in life but can't speak

action.name: Longsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) slashing damage, or 7 ({@damage 1d10 + 2}) slashing damage if used with two hands.

action.name: Longbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +4} to hit, range 150/600 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) piercing damage.

action.name: Glacial Touch {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 2}) cold. The target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@damage 1d4}) cold damage at the start of each of its turns, as a frozen shard lodges itself in the wound.  Any creature can take an action to remove the shard with a successful {@dc 12} Wisdom ({@skill Medicine}) check. The shard crumbles to snow if the target receives magical healing.
A humanoid slain by this attack rises in 1 week as a glacial corrupter, unless the humanoid is restored to life or its body is destroyed.
This skeleton's bones are crystal and caked with layers of frost and ice.

entries.name: Origin
entries: Glacial corrupters are similar in nature to most {@creature skeleton|mm|skeletons}, except their bones have been transformed into crystal by the dark magic that created them. Cold has permeated their forms to such an extent that they exude an unnatural cold that cannot be warmed. They come about in one of two ways: when a creature is killed by a glacial corrupter or when a creature is killed by a {@creature sapphire jelly|ToB2}.

entries.name: Limited Intelligence
entries: Glacial corrupters are much like basic skeletons in that they are not truly self-aware. They are undead who either follow the simple instructions of necromancers or other creatures that can control them, or they follow a basic drive to destroy any living creatures they encounter. They are often used as guardians who do not tire, or as part of an attacking force for a greater power. They have no memories of their previous lives.

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: A glacial corrupter doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

trait.name: Ground Disruptor
entries: When the glacier behemoth moves, it can choose to make the area it moves through difficult terrain. When it uses Inexorable Charge, it automatically makes the ground difficult terrain.

trait.name: Unstoppable
entries: Difficult terrain composed of ice, rocks, sand, or natural vegetation, living or dead, doesn't cost the glacier behemoth extra movement. Its speed can't be reduced by any effect.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The glacier behemoth makes two bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}33 ({@damage 4d12 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Inexorable Charge
entries: If the glacier behemoth moves at least 10 feet, it can then use this action to continue moving in a 40-foot line that is 15 feet wide. Each creature in this line must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) bludgeoning damage and is knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}. The glacier behemoth's movement along this line doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack|phb|opportunity attacks}.
A depression in the ground trails in the wake of this six-legged creature. Aged ice, appearing more like granite, covers the creature's body.

entries.name: Slow but Steady
entries: Glacier behemoths earn their name from their resemblance to glaciers, including their slow, relentless pace. Their squat frames help conceal their six legs, reinforcing the notion that they are calved glaciers. Short of chasms blocking its way or the intervention of other glacier behemoths, nothing can stop a glacier behemoth when it moves. Its tough hide combined with its primal intellect render it fearless as it lumbers after its foes.

entries.name: Bulettekin
entries: Glacier behemoths are arctic relatives to bulettes, but their existence predates their temperate land–inhabiting kin. They are just as aggressive as their smaller cousins, but they don't have the speed or agility bulettes possess. They are also not as particular about the type of food they eat, owing to the lack of choice in the barren lands they inhabit.

entries.name: Path of Destruction
entries: Weighing at least 15 tons, a glacier behemoth can't help but crush everything in its wake. It leaves deep furrows in the ground as wide as its body. A sure sign of a wandering glacier behemoth is a crisscrossing set of ditches.

Despite its lack of stealth, a glacier behemoth can still take a settlement by surprise thanks to its ability to dig through the earth. The behemoth burrows into a building through the floor and attacks anything it finds. After this initial assault, it devastates the rest of the settlement, picking off those foolish enough to stay and fight.

monster.name: Bearing Golem

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with adamantine weapons

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Ambusher
entries: In the first round of combat, the golem has advantage on attack rolls against any creature it has surprised.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the bearing golem is scattered, it is indistinguishable from a normal pile of ball bearings.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistances
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

trait.name: Reform
entries: If the golem is scattered and has at least 1 hit point, it can reform as a bonus action in any space containing at least one of its ball bearings without provoking an {@action opportunity attack}. If it reforms within 5 feet of a {@condition prone} creature, it can make one slam attack against that creature as part of this bonus action.

trait.name: Scatter
entries: As a bonus action, the bearing golem can disperse, scattering its ball bearings in a 15-foot cube, centered on the space it previously occupied. A creature moving through a space containing any of the golem's ball bearings must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or fall {@condition prone}. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesn't need to make the save. While scattered, the bearing golem can't attack or move, except to reform, and it can't be targeted by attacks or spells. It can still take damage from spells that deal damage in an area.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The golem makes two slam attacks. Alternatively, it uses its Steel Shot twice.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +7} pour toucher, portée de 1,5 m, une cible. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) dégâts de matraquage.

action.name: Steel Shot
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +7} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d6 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Scattershot {@recharge 5}
entries: The golem's body explodes. Each creature within 15 feet of the golem must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes 36 ({@damage 8d8}) bludgeoning damage and is knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}. The golem immediately scatters.
A scattering of metal ball bearings coalesces into a constantly shifting humanoid shape.
Made up of thousands of ball bearings, a bearing golem can assume nearly any shape it chooses, though it always remains an amalgamation of metal pellets.

entries.name: Thievish Inspiration
entries: The first bearing golem was created when a wizard saw a thief foiling the traps in its tower with ball bearings. After disposing of the thief, the wizard collected the metal balls and realized their purpose could be improved if the bearings spread themselves.

entries.name: Natural Ambushers
entries: Bearing golems regularly lie in wait for hours, days, even weeks, hiding as an innocuous, scattered pile of bearings. When travelers move through the bearings, the golem springs back together and attacks.

entries.name: Construct Nature
entries: The bearing golem doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

variant.name: Caltrop Golem
entries: Some particularly devious wizards create bearing golems out of {@item caltrop|phb|caltrops} instead of {@item ball bearings (bag of 1,000)|phb|ball bearings}. These caltrop golems deal piercing damage instead of bludgeoning damage, and, when the golem uses its Scatter trait, the area is covered with {@item caltrop|phb|caltrops} instead of {@item ball bearing (bag of 1,000)|phb|ball bearings}.

monster.name: Death Shroud Golem

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with adamantine weapons

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Fabric Form
entries: The golem can move through any opening large enough for a Tiny creature without squeezing.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While the golem remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a shroud, cloak, or similar piece of fabric.

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistances
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Smothering Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one Medium or smaller creature. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) bludgeoning damage, and the creature is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, {@condition blinded}, and unable to breathe, and the golem can automatically hit the target with its smothering slam but can't use its smothering slam on another target.

action.name: Direct Victim
entries: The death shroud golem forces a creature it is grappling to move up to the creature's speed and make one attack with a melee weapon the creature is holding. If the creature isn't holding a melee weapon, it makes one unarmed strike instead. The death shroud golem decides the direction of the movement and the target of the attack. The {@condition grappled} creature can use its reaction and isn't considered {@condition blinded} or {@condition restrained} when moving and attacking in this way.
A filthy burial shroud glides silently through the air, the vague features of a humanoid outlined on its cotton surface. The stench of an open grave hangs around it.

entries.name: Suffocating Automatons
entries: A death shroud golem is created from the used burial shroud of a humanoid. Most death shroud golems are stained with dirt, blood, or mold, and a few are covered in even more unsavory substances. Despite their appearance, death shroud golems are sturdy constructs and can take quite a beating. A death shroud golem typically strikes from a hidden location, grappling and suffocating its victim.

entries.name: Funerary Constructs
entries: Death shroud golems are normally found guarding tombs or other locations where their appearance wouldn't arouse suspicion. Occasionally, necromancers and intelligent undead wear death shroud golems like a cloak or robe, releasing the creature to attack their enemies.

entries.name: Construct Nature
entries: A death shroud golem doesn't require air, food, drink, or sleep.

monster.name: Dragonflesh Golem

immune.note: from nonmagical attacks not made with adamantine weapons

languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

trait.name: Immutable Form
entries: The golem is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Magic Weapons
entries: The golem's weapon attacks are magical.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The dragonflesh golem uses Terror Stare. It then makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d10 + 6}) piercing damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) slashing damage.

action.name: Terror Stare
entries: The dragonflesh golem chooses a creature that can see its eyes within 30 feet of it. The target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the golem's Terror Stare for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Elemental Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The dragonflesh golem exhales energy in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) fire damage and 21 ({@damage 6d6}) damage of another type on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Roll a {@dice d4} to determine the additional damage type: 1 is acid, 2 is cold, 3 is lightning, and 4 is poison.

A hulking being with a dragon's head and a patchwork of black, blue, green, red, and white scales for skin lurches forward on two legs, raising clawed fists into the air. Dragonflesh golems are rare constructs created from the remains of dead chromatic dragons.
